cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Long term change in average weather patterns.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Rise in average global temperature.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Gases in the atmosphere trap some outgoing heat (infrared radiation) and warm the Earth.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Extra greenhouse gases from human activity increase heat trapped.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Slow changes in Earth’s orbit and tilt that change how much solar energy reaches Earth.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Changes in the shape of Earth’s orbit (distance from the Sun varies over time).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Changes the strength of seasons and how solar energy is distributed.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: A wobble that changes the timing of seasons relative to Earth’s orbit.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Ash and sulphur aerosols can reflect sunlight → short-term cooling (months to a few years).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: The Sun’s energy output changes slightly over time and can influence climate on long timescales.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Burning coal/oil/gas releases CO₂. More CO₂ → more heat trapped → higher temperatures.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Less carbon stored + less photosynthesis; CO₂ can be released if trees burn/decay → higher CO₂.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Methane (CH₄) from cattle digestion and rice paddies; nitrous oxide (N₂O) from fertilisers.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Some industrial processes (including cement production) release CO₂ and other greenhouse gases.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Vehicles/planes/ships burn fossil fuels → CO₂ emissions.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Sea level rise: two main reasons
cards.back: Thermal expansion (warmer water expands) and melting of land ice (glaciers/ice sheets).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Coastal flooding, erosion, and saltwater intrusion into soils/groundwater.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Higher temperatures can increase intensity/frequency of some extremes (e.g., heatwaves, heavy rainfall; drought risk in some regions).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Melting glaciers/ice sheets: why it matters
cards.back: Contributes to sea level rise and can affect river flow in some places.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Habitats shift as climate changes → species migration, biodiversity loss, stress on coral/forests in some regions.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Oceans absorb heat and CO₂: warming affects marine ecosystems; CO₂ lowers pH, affecting shell-forming organisms.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Some places get wetter, others drier, and seasons can shift → affects water supply, floods, and farming.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Heat stress; spread of disease vectors in some regions; air quality issues from wildfire smoke.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Damage to property/infrastructure, insurance costs, impacts on farming/fishing/tourism.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back: Displacement, pressure on services, greater inequality where poorer groups can’t adapt.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
Mitigation = reduce the cause (cut emissions/increase sinks).
Adaptation = reduce the impact (prepare for/manage effects).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Mitigation: renewable energy (how it works + limits)
cards.back:
Replaces fossil-fuel electricity → lower CO₂.
Limits: intermittency, storage/grid upgrades, planning opposition, high initial cost.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Mitigation: energy efficiency (how it works + limits)
cards.back:
Uses less energy for same output → lower emissions.
Limits: upfront cost, slow adoption, rebound effect.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Mitigation: low-carbon transport (how it works + limits)
cards.back:
Public transport/EVs/cycling/rail reduce fossil fuel use.
Limits: charging infrastructure, battery materials, behaviour change, rural access.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
Captures CO₂ at source and stores it underground.
Limits: expensive, energy intensive, storage/safety concerns, not available everywhere.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
Trees absorb CO₂ (carbon sink).
Limits: land competition, time lag, fire/disease risk, not enough alone.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Mitigation: agreements & carbon pricing (how it works + limits)
cards.back:
Targets and incentives reduce emissions.
Limits: enforcement/politics, carbon leakage, fairness debates.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Adaptation: flood defences & coastal management (how + limits)
cards.back:
Sea walls/barriers/managed realignment reduce flood damage.
Limits: high cost/maintenance; can shift problems; cannot protect everywhere.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
Reservoirs/transfers/leakage reduction/demand management help drought risk.
Limits: cost, environmental impacts, user conflict, long planning times.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
Drought-tolerant crops, new planting dates, efficient irrigation, soil conservation.
Limits: cost, uncertainty, water availability.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.back:
Trees/green spaces, reflective surfaces, building design, cooling centres.
Limits: space, funding, unequal benefits, maintenance.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Adaptation: emergency planning & early warning (how + limits)
cards.back:
Forecasting + preparedness reduce harm.
Limits: forecast uncertainty, compliance, resources; severe events can still hit.

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Explain a cause: best answer structure
cards.back: Cause (name it) → Mechanism (how it changes energy balance/greenhouse gases) → Result (warming/cooling or changing climate patterns).

cards.subject: Geography
cards.front: Evaluate management: what you must include
cards.back: Compare effectiveness, cost, timescale, reliability/fairness + give limitations + finish with a justified conclusion.
